title: Investing Your Roth IRA at 18: The Case for One Fund
subtitle: Maximize Your Money Growth with a Focused Investment Strategy
content:
Investing Your Roth IRA at 18: The Case for One Fund

I'm Tyler, I'm a former financial advisor and portfolio manager, and now I make financial content for free so you don't have to pay for it.

1. Choose Vanguard's Growth ETF (VUG)

I would invest my Roth IRA exclusively in VUG, Vanguard's growth ETF. With an expense ratio of just 0.04%, it's literally the lowest in the industry for what you get. There's no need to diversify into dividend funds, bonds, or REITsâ€”especially when you've got decades of potential growth ahead of you.

2. Historical Returns

Growth funds like VUG have historically returned 10% to 12% in real terms (post-inflation). Over a span of 40 plus years, that kind of return compounds into a ridiculous amount of money.

3. Max Your Contributions

If you max out your Roth IRA every year, contributing $7,500 in 2026 (which is over $140 a week), and do that from age 18 to 65, at a 10% annual return, you'll end up with about $3.4 million. That's 100% tax-free, post-inflation, all from just one fund and one decisive investment.
